reviewText:
Pros:-Gameplay is really fun and addicvitve.
-A simple 4-button battle system that's full of finesse and is very responsive.
-The story, while somewhat confusing at times, is satisfying once you get through it.
-Character interactions and story arcs that make the characters feel like real people, particularly Rem and Machina.

Cons:-Graphics definitely look like an HD port of a PSP game, with muddy textures and some NPC faces looking pretty flat and low-poly.
-Lack of graphics options, the launcher settings are limited to shadows, motion blur and textures, with some options only going up to Normal" setting. Perhaps a hi-res texture/shadow pack will arrive in the future (or modded in) but for now we're looking at a pretty crappy variety of graphical options.

NOTE: This game is locked to 30fps due to engine limitations

reviewText:
I'm one of the (seemingly) few people that had the luck to have played the PSP version of Final Fantasy Type-0 before having purchased this version.  For this reason, my opinions might not resonate as well with some of you as with others.  Bearing this in mind, I've come to appreciate this game for what it does well (combat and story), even in spite of what it does not do well (this list is longer).

First, the graphics are going to be a sore spot for many that have played and that will play this game.  The cliche argument is that, since Final Fantasy Type-0 HD is a current-gen port of a PSP game, our expectations concerning graphic fidelity must be tailored accordingly.  This is true, but I don't think it is entirely fair, either.  I doubt there are as many people out there that genuinely seem to be affected by graphics as the trolls might suggest, but Square Enix has unintentionally made this issue worse than it had to be.  This is because they decided to rework graphics in some areas, while leaving others indistinguishable from their PSP counterparts.  This is apparent in textures, character models, etc.

Now, that doesn't sound so bad, but when you consider the fact that changed and unchanged models and textures can appear in tandem, the difference between new and old is made more stark.  The earliest example of this that I can think of occurs after the first mission, where General Qator Bashtar (with a relatively updated model) appears next to a random imperial grunt (whose model was not updated).  The difference is jarring, and it casts the game in a poor light relatively early on.  Now, I don't care about graphics in the least, but to say things like this are not noticeable is a pretty ludicrous claim.

Second, the gameplay.  Square Enix got it right this time.  I thoroughly enjoy games in the Kingdom Hearts series, but I worry that I'll get diabetes from the sickly-sweet tone and story.  Well, Final Fantasy Type-0 HD takes what the Kingdom Hearts games do right in terms of combat, and pairs it with a much more mature plot (to be discussed further down).  In Final Fantasy Type-0 HD, you are given fourteen playable characters with relatively distinct archetypes ranging from slow, heavy melee (Cinque and Jack) to quick melee (Machina, Seven, Eight, Rem) to quick ranged (King, Ace, Cater), to slow ranged (Trey), to buffbots (Deuce and kinda Queen) and pretty much everywhere in between.  The game gives you many ways to play, and is likely to please any player that enjoys action RPGs.  Combat is further augmented with Killsights and Breaksights, which leverage the game's lock-on system to allow the player to deliver powerful attacks on opponents at certain times (usually tethered to the target's activity).  Magic is sufficiently powerful, as well, though it may seem more costly in the early game than in the end.  Summons are one of the game's weak points, as I've found that Eidolons are generally not worth using unless you absolutely have to, since the forced death that they inflict on you is reflected in your post-mission statistics and score.

Missions are fun, and they can take place in either a pure-combat corridor style similar to some FPS games, or they can take on a more RTS-like feel in campaign missions.  I've found both to be enjoyable, though how much enjoyment I take from the game is dependent on the mission itself.  One notable improvement in this version of Type-0, as opposed to the PSP version, is that you can replay the RTS missions from the main menu.  This was not possible in the PSP version, which always irked me, since I would've liked to have been able to replay them from time to time, as you might be tempted to do if you need to grind levels to get past a roadblock, in typical JRPG fashion.  The missions themselves tend to be fairly combat-heavy, with some other objectives sometimes interspersed amidst the carnage.

Next, the story.  Type-0 does not spoon feed the story to its players, so you'll probably need to spend some time reading the Rubicus (the game's in-world encyclopedia) to get all the background information necessary to appreciate what is going on in the world.  I think the game is better for this, though.  Orience is a place whose complexity seemingly mirrors our own world in its sheer depth.  I certainly wouldn't expect any game about our world to be immediately and completely understandable to any external players.  As the game progresses, the stakes of the war at hand escalate until a victor is decided, but the end is sudden, abrupt, and brutal.  It took me a fair amount of external reading to make sense of it, which is rare.  At the end of the day, though, I consider the story to have actually been one of this game's stronger points.

One of the worst changes I think they could have made with respect to this version of Final Fantasy Type-0 is the complete removal of its multiplayer component.  Honestly, when I first heard that Type-0 was being remade for consoles, a revision of its multiplayer sprang forth as one of the first overdue changes that would be made.  The original PSP version had a sort of local multiplayer that required people to convene and play together, despite the fact that the Internet was a thing.  Granted, it's not like we needed Link Cables or any other such antiques to engage in jolly cooperation, but the game came out in 2011 and eschewed the seemingly more user-friendly Internet-based option for something that parents nowadays probably tell their children about when the Internet is out in true back in my day..." fashion.  However

reviewText:
This is probably the bloodiest, darkest game in the Final Fantasy franchise yet. Opening cut scene contains a soldier and his chocobo being gunned down. It's sad but it sets the tone in the game and leaves you wanting more.

+ On a scale of 1 to Crisis Core, the story is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing emotional.
+ Beautiful soundtrack
+ All 14 playable characters each have their own unique abilities.
+ Fully controllable summons. (Shiva is cute af)
+ Interesting side missions.
+ Baby chocobos

reviewText:
Great combat lost in a mediocre game
Let me start this off by saying I'm a huge fan of Final Fantasy games both old and new, and am always excited by where they take the series. That said, this game preserves a few of the worst aspects of the series and doesn't quite make up for it enough with what it tries to do.

First, it's very obvious that this was a PSP game. Low-resolution textures, stilted cutscenes where characters just stand and talk at each other, and a camera that swings wildly for no reason at all while locked onto enemies make the game a lot harder to digest than one might expect from a different, bigger-budget title. Some games find ways to shine through these issues, but unfortunately Type-0 is not one of them.

Managing fourteen different party members is tiresome, and most of them don't recieve any character development besides a one-dimensional attribute. While the ability to navigate towns and the overworld as any character is a welcome touch, the symptom of this is your character doesn't have any meaningful interactions with the world, and often interacting with other characters shows you a scene that your character isnt even in. If you are the type of person that likes to understand ambient dialogue, you're out of luck. The english dub is atrocious, clearly made by paying the lowest-budget actors possible to simply read their lines off of a page. They also like to pause in their sentences where the subtitles stop on the screen, even if it makes no sense in the sentence. I'm guessing this is a symptom of some sort of PSP audio buffering where they had to divide up the audio files, but I've never noticed it in other heavily voice-acted PSP games so maybe I'm just giving them too much credit.

The story isnt necessarily bad, the world is an interesting take on the Nova Crystalis universe, and the opening cutscene is incredible. However, after the game's opening, the story is mostly told through stilted dialogue sequences and war documentary-style voiceovers, with very little in the way of actual character or action. The soundtrack is forgettable and plays softly in the background of these sequences, never shaping the emotion of the scenes.

The gameplay loop seems fun at first glance, but quickly becomes tiresome. The actual draw of the game, the missions, happen somewhat rarely, and much of the sidequests consist of wandering the empty overworld hunting for specific random battles. To make matters worse, you can only hold one sidequest at a time, though quests to deliver monster drops thankfully let you farm those drops while completing other missions. Still, this system often results in you wasting time trekking all the way back to turn in quest just so you can accept another quest that you could have completed at the same time. There's no excuse for this system, especially since the game is further slowed down by random battles on the overworld rather than a more modern approach such as overworld monsters.

The one thing this game does absolutely right is its combat. The breaksight/killsight system, essentially giving you moments of opportunity" before or after enemy attacks to do massive damage

reviewText:
Great game with minor issues // Problems with keyboard and mouse
Believe it or not, but this is my first Final Fantasy game. Despite that, I decided that I wanted to review it.

+ Fairly long, took me about 60 hours to beat it once, but then again I play like a tortoise.
+ Game looks great, especially Class Zero and a couple of other NPC's. Same goes for certain maps as well.
+ Story is engaging enough if you're into that.
+ A likable main cast that are well fleshed out. They're fairly cliché, but they also gets the job done. In this point I also want to include that there are a lot of playable characters, each with their own set of abilities and playstyle. You will most certainly find a favorite amongst them, and one of the greatest parts of the game for me was experimenting with all of them to figure out which one suited me the best.
+ Good replayability, if you want to experience everything you will have to play it through at least twice, and with several difficulty levels and the amount of characters available this will not be boring.
+ Combat was a bit difficult for me to get into at the beginning, but once I got the hang of it I was treated to one of the best combat systems I've experienced in recent years.
+ Voice acting is nice, although I thoroughly despised the English voices. The Japanese voices are amazing however.
+ No major difficulty spikes as you're encouraged to explore. If you find yourself underleveled, there is always the arena and special training.
+ Skill improvement for both abilities and magic is pretty fun, since you won't be able to unlock everything in a single playthrough most of the time.
+ Fun conversations/cutscenes and quests around the main hub.
+ Death system works great, and you're encouraged to try to keep everyone alive in order to get as high a rating as possible on missions.
+ Super speed for when you want to move from one place to another quickly.
+ In my opinion, a great ending. (reminded me of Mass Effect though...)

- A controller is a must if you are going to play this. Don't get me started on how poorly optimized mouse and keyboard is for this game.
- Textures for everything but Class Zero is generally pretty bad. Though since this is a remastered PSP game that is fairly forgivable. If you're not the type of person that cares much about graphics (like me), you will likely not mind the occasional Tomb Raider III type of graphics.
- Not very noob friendly, while it does explain all the major aspects of the game, some things are left out.
- The antagonists are not very memorable, and neither is the plot as a whole.
- While you're given the freedom to explore freely, there is time limit on how much you can do at once. Later on this was reversed and I was given more freedom than the US but not enough stuff to do.
- Side quests, while fun, are not as many as I had hoped for. Especially when you visit minor towns there are often only one quest to do in each, and you probably won't need to return to that town ever again.

All in all, I can definitely recommend this game. In the beginning I was not sure whether or not I wanted to continue playing it, but I'm glad I did. This has been all I've been playing for some time now and I don't want to put it down anytime soon. If you got the money to spare, or even better, if it's on sale, don't think twice about picking it up!

that is, if you have a controller

reviewText:
This is not your typical Final Fantasy. And yet, it succeeds where past entries in the main series failed: it captures the Final Fantasy magic while adding its own identity and mixing the formula. The game has its flaws, but most of them have more to do with its portable nature than game design.

The story is about a group of elite cadets called Class Zero. The game starts as your nation, Rubrum, is invaded by the adjacent empire and almost succeeds in seizing the crystal from which all of your magic comes. Class Zero manages to repel the enemy forces, but Rubrum loses a considerable chunk of territory. The plot revolves around the resulting war (and more, but let's not spoil anything, okay?)

Gameplay is fantastic. Not because it is innovative. It is an action RPG with pretty standard controllers. You dodge, attack and use special skills and magic. However, three things make it great:

1. It is incredibly smooth. This version fixed the blurry camera and you don't need to lock on enemies all the time (though you'll end up doing it anyway, because of killstrikes.) Everything is responsive and intuitive.

2. There's an enourmous cast of characters, and every one of them feels different. Some dodge better, some are ranged,  others attack faster or may even finish combos with AoE attacks. Every one of them has a distinct advantage (and disavantage) that changes the way you experience the game.

3. Combat is strategic. The game will punish you for dishing out attacks without thought (some enemies will just dodge forever.) Also, attacking at a specific window of opportunity signaled by a visual cue will kill the enemy instantly, or at least deal considerable damage, if the enemy is too strong. It rewards you for playing the game well.

As for sounds and graphics, it is a mixed bag. Soundtrack is great and sound effects are perfect, as with any Final Fantasy, but the voice acting is surprisingly bad. Most voices are decent to good, actually, but when they're bad, they're distractingly awful. Graphics got an overhaul. Kinda. Main cast looks amazing and new lighting effects make for beautiful screenshots, but most NPCs and towns look blocky and with low-res textures.

Actually, the main problem with this game on PC is that it was designed for a portable system. So the portable design is all there: it's grindy, towns and dungeons are mostly corridors and dialogues are poorly animated. But don't get me wrong: there are absolutely more good parts than bad ones. In fact, even as a portable game, it surpasses its Fabula Nova console counterpart Final Fantasy XIII in content. There are tons of sidequests, open world map with explorable dungeons, you can breed chocobos, liberate towns... You'll definitely get your money's worth in gameplay hours.

Now, the reason this game really gets to me: it is a fantastic deviation of the Final Fantasy usual tone. This game is all about death, but it chose not to take the easy route. Yes, there's a lot of killing and blood. But it doesn't stop there. It permeates the story, with its constant war. Characters in this world have their memory of the dead erased, so they can continue their neverending battles. In gameplay, fellow members of Class Zero can't be revived until the end of the mission. If they die, they stay dead until you go back. Eidolons need sacrifices to be summoned and magic is upgraded with Phantoma, which you harvest from the dead. It is a fantastic change of tone, well executed and more than welcome.

Now, this is not a good port. It is resolution and frame locked. It has terrible performance issues (I can only get steady 30fps at all times without AA.) Keyboard layout is awkward and can't be changed, so you need to play with a controller for a decent gameplay experience.  Basically, it has none of the advantages PC gaming usually has over console gaming.

But what I really want to say is:

Is this a good port? No.
Is this an incredible addition to Steam's jRPG library? Hell yeah.

reviewText:
I've never played the PSP version of it so this is my first try on a port to PC. A must play for any fans of the Final Fantasy series. Completed my first run through of the game in about 42 hours. With that being said, I'll state the pros first before the cons.

Pros
-Interactive battle system.
-Up to 14 characters for you to choose and master, each with a different playstyle.
-One of the best storylines out there amongst the series.
-Traditional Eidolon summons such as Shiva, Odin, Ifrit.
-Soundtrack is amazing, as expected from Square Enix
-Japanese VAs are unparalleled.
-New game+ after completing the game for the first time.
-Chocobos.

Cons
-Needs a controller for a good gameplay experience.
-Locking on system is abit clunky. Sometimes the items on the floor might be just infront of you and it takes ages for the system to detect.
-AIs are abit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at times, not hitting mobs, range supports not targetting aerial units etc etc.
-FPS drops to about 15 on certain parts of the maps.
-Certain boss fights are confusing, sometimes I'm not even sure if characters dying due to overpowered moves from bosses are part of the progress.
-Gets grindy if you wish to unlock end-tier items for your characters.

Overall would rate this game a 9/10.

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY : Reminds me of FF12 with a more mobile gameplay but less actions (although customizable). Lock-ons and targetting is clunky at first but you get the hand of it later on as the game progresses. If you like the more traditional style then this type of gameplay isn't for you. Skills and loadouts are fun to play around with and the AI for your teammates are mediocre so you'll see yourself swapping controls frequently in combat (with the exception of AI Deuce since she is amazing). Game also has its traditional summons like Ifrit and Shiva which require a heavy price to pay for using them. All the characters are versatile and have their own set of skills so play around with your favourites. Definitely need a controller to enjoy the gameplay - currently using a DS3 Controller and can't see myself playing this with a keyboard/mouse.

STORY : Story is alright. Not the best writing since I see myself paying attention more to the gameplay and sidequests, but I do find some areas of the story interesting. Considering it was originally a PSP game, good enough.

VISUALS : HD version has made a huge difference for sure. If the original was ported, this would not look as great as it is now (still not up to par with other FF games but once again it is good for a PSP port to PC). Bit of frame rate issues here and there but fixed (at least for me) by optimizing graphic settings.

AUDIO : As you'd expect from any FF game.

SCORE : 3.5/5 Yet to finish and only 9 hours in. The clunky start did affect my score but as I continue playing I am positive I'd reconsider and give it a 4/5 later on.

reviewText: As a casual fan of final fantasy I wasn't really sure what to expect with type 0 but to be honest so far I'm fairly impressed. For a game that was on the PSP it looks about how I would expect. Some textures are clearly left over from the PSP but all in all I can't complain to much about the graphics on a game released 4 years ago on a hand held. I haven't finished the game yet but the story so far seems interesting enough and fairly typical of final fantasy with a bit of a darker feel. The gameplay however is what makes this game a definite recommendation for me. It has completely moved away from any sort of turn based actions during combat and feels a lot like kingdom hearts in terms of combat. However, just because it has taken out the turn based actions doesn't mean the strategy is gone. Class 0 has a diverse group of skills and learning how to manage them to make the best parties to overcome certain areas takes a bit of thought. Also learning how to use each character has been fun as they all have a different play style that takes getting used too. The time management between missions I found cool as it makes you think on what is most important for your team and what you can get done in the alotted time. So if you are looking for a game with ground breaking graphics this probably isn't for you but, if you want a game that offers an fun and thoughtful action you might want to check this out.

reviewText: This is a PSP port. A lot of people don't seem to understand that. The port isn't perfect and is poorly optimized in my opinion but that doesn't change the fact that the game itself has been quite fun so far. Considering the platform of origin, I think that the game looks pretty good. Some textures are bad, like they didn't get touched up. A lot of people are upset by 30 FPS and 1080p as the maximum resolution, (why you would want a psp port in 4k is beyond me, but whatever.) I can see where it could be disappointing, but I come from a time where technical specs were backseat to the game actually being fun to play.\n\nI can't comment too much on the story yet, but from what i've played its been alright. The gameplay has been quite fun, and with a wide variety of characters you can approach combat in different ways. I'll likely update this review later after i've played some more but for now I want to get it out that that the game is enjoyable if you're not caught up in the massive graphic/spec circle jerk and actually like to play games.

reviewText:
Where do I start?

Final Fantasy Type - 0 is probably my favorite FF to date, even back when I played it on the PSP. It was a wierd turn of direction for Square, but damn was it an awesome direction to go towards. Just how Sega went a different direction with Sonic by making Shadow the Hedgehog have guns and violence, Square went a different direction with Type-0 with possibly one of the most brutal and jarring intro's to a Final Fantasy game we've seen to date. The radical departure might unease some die-hard fans, but for others it brought to light a different perspective in the Final Fantasy universe that we haven't seen.

Anyways, let's talk about the Graphics.

FF: Type - 0's HD remake has done a splendid job of remaking a PSP game into a solid PC game. As a person who generally had little faith in Square's ports (Having experienced FFXIII Being Awful, as well as FFXIII - 2) I was pretty sketchy coming into it, expecting some horribly botched port that wouldn't be worth the time of day. I was pleasantly surprised and can say that without a doubt, this is probably the best port Square's done to date for a Final Fantasy game.

The graphics have been overhauled, yet there are still remnants of it's PSP origin. Namely, some of the sprite and texture work can still be blotchy/sketchy in some areas. However, they've made an already impressively and beautiful Akademia on the PSP look even more awesome by HD'ing it. If you look at the scenery of some of the area's too, and all the pretty effects they added you can take a small moment to enjoy what they've done with the game. But let's face it, you don't care about that. You probably have one jarring question that is going to determine whether or not you buy this game.

Is it 60 FPS?
No. It's not.

Why? It's because the game itself is dependant on things operating at that speed. Try going into skyrim and disabling your frame limiter and Vsync and watch the physics engine go willy nilly. You're asking for the same thing here by complaining that you want the game to be in 60 FPS.

For once in my life, I'm defending 30FPS. ......-Facepalm- But it's true. Despite me also believing it should be an industry standard, as a person who played this on the PSP and thought the game ran -extremely- well for a PSP game despite all the crap that was happening, the same feeling extends to the PC. There are times when I hardly notice the 30 FPS either to be honest. And let me give you a pro tip. If you feel the games too slow, they introduced a speed up button to the game that makes everything move at 1.5x speed, essentially making the game feel faster both frame wise and pace-wise.

The graphics options are actually pretty plentiful, if we're being biased towards Square. The jarring fail here though is their locked resolutions of either 1920x1080p or 1280 x 720. Personally, my PC can't handle the game at 1920x1080p with all of the settings, so I usually play in a windowed mode because it also lets me keep track of other tasks on my PC. You have the options of customizing shadows, motion blur effects (which are an awesome addition to make the game feel more cinematic and action-y <--- Legit word, I promise)



Now let's talk about the Gameplay.

Type-0 is a radical departure from it's predacessors in that it's a hack and slash based game. With an impressive roster of FOURTEEN PLAYABLE CHARACTERS, EACH INCREDIBLY UNIQUE IN THEIR GAMEPLAY, you're guaranteed to find at least one member of class zero that suits your fancy. My personal favorite is Seven.

Battles happen as thus: You have your typical overfield random battles, that throw you in a sandbox-like area where you duke it out with the enemy forces in real-time hack and slash based combat. When you defeat the enemy forces, there's a chance that you have the ability to go another round" with the same enemies
date: only they'll be stronger. You can do this up to four times
recommended: and the enemies levels will increase
hoursPlayed:
as well as the chance of them becoming enraged. (they don't flinch and deal stupid amounts of damage)

Combat itself in the game is fast-paced and has a degree of skill to it. Essentially if you're locked onto a target a 'Kill Marker" will appear on an enemy if it's in a position that leaves it vulnerable. Striking an enemy while this "Kill Marker' is up let's you score a critical hit that usually will kill the creature in one hit.

Missions are a bit different
voteText: as they usually have some relevance to the story and pit you in a location against enemy forces. These are replayable from the main menu and can be done as many times as you want
helpfulPercent: which is a cool function if you really liked a particular mission.\n\nWhen you're not in missions

votesFunny: as you simply won't have enough time to get through all of them. Missing events between missions can also prevent you from seeing that event in the future too

You can also additionally recieve backup from Akademia itself which lets you earn some points towards unlocking some nice gear.\n\nWhen I finally get around to beating it this time around and actually being able to understand the story

reviewText:
I played Final Fantasy Type-0 before on PSP and I truly enjoyed playing this game and highly recommend this title.
As for FF Type-0 HD for PC (Steam), unfortunately at this current state, I have to choose not to recommend. It feels like this game was not even tested at all before selling it here. If Square Enix can fix these major issues ASAP, that would be great and I definitely recommend this game, especially to Final Fantasy fans.

Just like most players, here are issues I experienced:
1) Frame rate dropped to 9fps!
My device is above the recommended spec yet this game's frame rate dropped as if I run 10 games at the same time! This is ridiculous! Cut-scenes stuttered horribly and I have not even started controlling my characters yet!
The 'temporary fix' would be having lower-res graphic settings by selecting 'Low-spec' at One-click Setup in Graphics section (or manually select your preferred lower-res settings). The low-spec setup that I set did help, but still, it was not completely smooth.  And of course, playing on low-res makes the game looks crappy.

2) This game is not meant to play with keyboard
This game definitely needs requires game controller in order to play comfortably. This game does not detect my controller (Logitech Rumblepad 2) although x360ce detected it (Yes, I have put it in WIN folder and set my Input to 'Controller', mind you).
I also stumbled upon an article and tried the suggested fixes (refer to: https://steamcommunity.com/app/340170/discussions/0/528398719790083423/ at x360ce issue section ) yet same thing, the game still fails to detect. This part could just be my controller being too old, though it works fine in other games.
When I forced myself to play with keyboard, I was completely at lost.

Honestly, I already smelled something fishy when this game is way cheaper than the PS4 and Xbox One version, yet I still believe in Square Enix and proceeded with the purchase. What a disappointment.

reviewText:
No the port is not perfect,
Yes it's locked at 30 FPS,
No the graphic upgrade doesn't apply everywhere,
Yes the gameplay is great,
Yes you will have lots of fun with a controller,

This game was made in 2011, for PSP not PS3. Of course you would expect it to have inferior graphics compared to 2015 PC AAA titles. People need to learn how to appreciate old games (especially graphically) the way they were meant to be played back in the day. To play this game with mouse and keyboard is as nonsensical as playing minecraft on a controller. I know some of you would disagree and point out that 3rd person movement with WASD like in GTA V would be great for this game. I agree that it would have been great if they could do it. However, the reality is that this game was not 'future proofed' for porting to PC and therefore while possible, I'm guessing that it would probably have made 3rd person play with a mouse extremely unoptimized with bugs, glitches and the like.

Conclusion, buy it if you have a controller

Have a look at this article if you want to know more about the graphics setting or would like to tweak things a bit more to your liking. The 'normal' setting should be good enough for most people by the way. pc gamer Final Fantasy Type-0 port analysis

Hope this helps :)

reviewText: I think that this game is worth playing for anyone who enjoys Final Fantasy games. Granted, as a port of a PSP game, it doesn't run the smoothest, but if you can look past that, you've got yourself a good purchase here. The main theme of this game is life and death, something the game does a fantastic job of reminding you of constantly. Managing the 14 playable party members keeps you from going with the same party of 3 throughout the game (as I used the two new characters to Class Zero, Machina and Rem, the most. Spoiler alert, they aren't allowed to participate in the final mission.) The side quests are rather fun, you can get your own airship, breed chocobos, and even get ambushed on the world map by enemies you can visibly see that are level 99 and kill you instantly! Some parts of the game are indeed annoying, yes, but past those, it's a fun game. If you're a fan of Final Fantasy and themixed" rating is making you question buying the game

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. Everything seemed tailored to my tastes and sensibilities. But the game kept annoying me with more and new things every 10 minutes. From the terrible lock on camera (you will most likely suffer whiplash when locking on to fast enemies as the camera follows the target TOO precisely), unresponsive controls with most of the characters, questionable design choices (forced deaths, acceptable quests that cannot be completed on new game, the entire RTS minigame, etc.), probably the worst cast across all of final fantasy including mainline and spin offs, non-plot with crazy stuff happening in last 30 minutes, the list just goes on.

With all that said, there are positive aspects. The combat is a good foundation on which I hope SE will build in the next type-XX game. Main theme of the game is breathtaking and is worthy of being in a Final Fantasy game. Final Boss is extremely climactic and marries video game narrative with the game mechanics.

All in all I would not recommend buying this, unless you are dead set on making your own opinion and/or game is on sale.

Japanese voice track included, Square enix seems to know what they're doing in this regard, as they are providing it in every japanese game they release. Shame that Miyuki Sawashiro is wasted on an annoying character. At least Tomokazu Sugita is cool and reasonable.

+659 bonus otaku points for voice actin, soundtrack and visual character design.

reviewText:
First of all, just to set things right : we don't care about those 30 fps.

This game is a remaster of a psp game that came out 4 years ago. Not a full remake. Don't expect it to be so beautiful that your eyes will burn of pleasure in front of a next gen ultra realistic game. The game still looks good and IS better than the psp version. Btw I don't really care about that, I'm more interested by the gameplay and the story.

Talking about that, the gameplay kinda reminds me of Final Fantasy Crisis Core that was also on psp, and appears to have been made by the same producer. I like it, you can choose between the 14 characters and decide which gameplay suits you the best. (Rem & Deuce <3)

The story is as always in FF games really interesting and deep. It uses the same mythology as in the FF XIII serie (don't shout OMG, these were good games D: ), so you may need to check it out to fully understand the background of the story. But you'll need at least 2 walkthroughs and a few explanations to completely understand what really happened, especially at the end of the game (OMG suspens). You'll miss a lot of the story if you don't bother wandering around during your free time to speak to everyone in Academeia. Still, as the game progress, you want to know even more what will happen to our class Zero cadets and feel more and more concerned about them, that's how you end loving a game.

Just to speak about the soundtrack (which is important), I love it. Especially the song Zero" by BUMP OF CHICKEN that is amazing

reviewText:
EPIC DARK SONG ABOUT WAR AND FRIENDSHIP!

Story: Best FF story I have been playing so far (IV, V, VII, VIII, IX, XIII). Why? You ask? Dark and twisted plot ever!  It's not about love anymore, it's about war and relationship amongs comrades! There is some romance indeed, but the whole game is soaked in sacrifice and heart-broken feelings. You should try to exploit all available endings.

Characters: There are 14 characters you can play, yet SE did a good job to distinguish personalities and characteristics between every single one of them. They are both at high school age but already strong in mind and body. You cannot forget one even you didn't tag along with him/her well in the game. Furthermore, with side quests and communication with NPCs throughout the game, you could find out more about their habbits, hobbies and more. This is a gold mine for mangaka or novelist!

Gameplay: the triple chars combat control it's not really impressive and new, yet they still bring entertainment throughout the game. Of course with total of 14 playable chars, you will have a hard time to choose which one is the best and try a lot of combination. Once you get familiar with the game, you will find it's not too hard and you will only play with favorite chars. Howerver, SE knew this and they require you take a good care of all of them, or at least 6 members to do some rotation in later part of the game. If you have played The Last Remnant, another good game of SE, you should be fine with all char development.

Time is essential and it is a very important element in Type 0 HD. You have a very litmited time to do quests and travel around. Communicating with other NPCs and chars could gain some extra hours but it is not much. So choose wisely! (you will have chance to accomplish all once you finish and play New game +, do not worry much!)

Besides RPG, the game includes RTS elements as well. You will command army and squad and do some strategic move to decide outcome of battles. Quite interesting!

Sad news for explorers: Type 0 HD's world  is not as big as other FF games. But it still contains some amusing hidden areas with treasures and surprises. And you still need chocobos to travel around!

Ah chocobos! Type 0 HD has a good chocobos breeding system that you can experience and produce some rare chocobos to support you in travelling and combating! And that's all! Not much but enough for this game.

The camera is sometime annoying with bad view angle and motion, but when you get to the speed and control, everything should be fine. I suggest you play with a controller, Xbox one should be good.

Graphics: it's a HD version of PSP version years ago, not quite beautiful and stunning for current trends but it's overally good. Characters and weapons are well done with high texture details. Environment isn't as good as characters but you still WOW when first visit the Academy.  Skill effects and summoning cutscene are still SE style: awesome and epic.

Sound: not really a strong point of game, sometimes it is repeatitive and annoying.

Music: Epic theme and music that suitable for war backgroud of the game. And remember to stay tune until last second of credit after you finish the game, one of the best song of FF is there, with heart broken scene too T_T

Pros:
- Dark and twisted story
- Various playable characters with interesting characteristics
- Trio character combat control brings some entertaining and strategic choice

Cons:
- Combat is repeatitive
- Trio character combat with NPCs is bad with poor AI and power.
- Small world to explore

RATE: 8.5/10

reviewText:
First the specs of my PC
16GB RAM, Intel 3770, nVidia 670.  Not top of the line, but not low end either.

First let me address the 30 fps.  I could understand the limit since it's a port.  Likely there's some timings tied with the frame rate (this has been done with some racing games and raising the FPS causes oddities).

But lets talk about the HD in the name.  I had the games AA set to high (because if I set it to Highest the frame rate drops to about 18).  Which AA it's using I'm unsure as it's not actually labeled but even with the second to highest AA available there's a lot of jagged edges.  So I forced AA through the nVidia control panel.  32x CSAA with 8X super sample and I got a solid 30fps.  Which means thier implementation of AA is terrible.   Second, the only thing that is actually HD is your characters, everything else looks like it's from a PS2.  There was very little effort put into making this port or making it HD.  Constantly things they improved" just stand out and feel out of place with the untouched environment.

The load screens/transitions.  This ties into this being a lazy port.  While the load screens are super short since I'm playing on a PC and not the original device this was released on (PSP)

reviewText:
As fan of the Final Fantasy™ franchise (I own every single Final Fantasy title including the ones not part of the main series, i.e, Tactics, Ehrgeiz, Dirge of Cerberus, Crisis Core, X-2, XIII-2, Lightning Returns, BUT excluding the MMO's.) My review is going to be quite bias. So downvote me if you like I'm going to give my personal opinion and experience of this game.

I pre-ordered this game for the Dota 2 chocobo courier, wallpaper and moogle ward. I absolutely like the game, the plot, battle dynamics, gameplay, and of course exceptionally well done soundtrack. I've waited 4 years for this game to be released in North America (it wasn't even suppose to leave Japan originally but it gained so much interest that they did bring it over. So there's my gratitude there).

This has got to be the darkest story plot of any Final Fantasy game, to the point where I started to get a 'Persona 3' feel near the ending. This game does offer multiple endings (3 different endings if I'm not mistaken, plus a hidden trailer for the upcoming game Type-1?). Yes, the game is a bit pixelated but it was still a good port imo and you may be discouraged that it's not in 60fps but that's okay, it ran smoothly for me.

Pros/Cons

+ You also have a variety of waifu's to choose from like: Deuce, Cater, Cinque, Sice, Seven, Queen, & Rem
+ Husbandos if you prefer: Ace, Trey, Eight, Nine, Jack, King, & Machina
+ Plenty of replay value (i.e collecting all the Ultimate weapons for every character, multiple endings)
+ Including side quests and multiple cutscenes depending on which character you are using.
+ The combat system doesn't get too boring.
+  Let's just say you fight a battle on a big bridge with a certain someone.
+ Fast learning curve
+ Great Soundtrack
+ Simple (You won't get lost or stuck in this game).

- You have to level them up three at a time, which can be quite time consuming.
- Single player whereas the PSP version offered Co-OP. It would be nice to game up with some friends.
-  The love story between Machina and Rem was lacking
- They could've done more character develpment and plot building.
- 30fps cap

reviewText:
Final Fantasy Type 0 wants to be a game about the suffering and cost of war.....yet still gives you panty shots whenever you dodge roll with a female character....damn I love Japanese man. The game play is rock ♥♥♥♥ing solid. Square has finally made a fun real time FF game. Sure the camera ♥♥♥♥s you sometimes but it's a PSP port what did you expect? All 14 characters are varied in combat and fun to play. The plot is meh until it absolutely falls apart at the last second (it's a JRPG tradition at this point).

Verdict: If you're an FF fan you already own the game. For those on the fence it's a solid sale game.

WARNING! DO NOT use anti-aliasing in the game. The method used by the game renders it in 4k then downgrades it to your resolution to get rid of the jagged lines. This is what kills your frame rate (why Square thought this was a good idea idk). Turn it off in the game start up UI and force anti-aliasing through your GPU.

reviewText:
Short Version:

FF type-0 is what I've come to expect from a FF entry, great gameplay, so-so soundtrack, terrible story. Forget the FF title as much as you can, lower your expectations, and you might find yourself having a good time.


Long Version:

Gameplay - Taking aside the port side of things (rigid controller settings, next to no support for anything outside xbox, yadda yadda) this game plays very nice, the combat is interesting and can be approached in a variety of gameplay styles, there are a lot of different missions/objectives and the newgame+ mechanic feels well integrated with new stuff to do each spin of the cycle.

Story - Loosely based on the same universe as the XIII's entries, the story tries to take a more mature approach with a constant war setting and lots of convictions/lives and blood/deaths on the table. The plot is extremely convoluted and can only be understood after replaying the game 2/3 times while actively seeking side content and reading material in-game, most characters are underdeveloped and/or overlooked. All this makes for a very poor excuse of story that ends in only a semi-pleasent note.

Sound - The main theme is pretty powerful and the composer seems to know since it is used as melody throughout too much of the soundtrack. There are some decent tracks and most of them fit the setting but the overuse of the main melody screams half ♥♥♥♥♥ job. The japanese VA is, of course, extremely welcome as it fits like a glove.

Graphics - The movie like scenes look very good and are a pleasure to watch. On other hand, the in-game cutscenes look terrible, with worse than soap opera you talk
date: I talk" conversations and only a few select body movements for each character. As for the game itself
hoursPlayed: but there aren't a ton of different areas."

reviewText:
Being a final fantasy fan what can i say about this one. I am on the final chapter so i will soon have it beat i have around 60% of the achievements i may or may not 100% it  I am about 23 hours in or so
====================================================================================
Gameplay
The battle system is a mix between kngdom hearts and star ocean. You have your 4 button commands and single use item. Though just like star ocean you can open up your menu to use items in the middle of combat. Learn how the evade system works because you will be timing between dodging and attacking.

The game pretty much forces you to learn how to dodge certain enemies can kill you in one hit with a status known as killstreak.  You can inflict it on enemies as well with well timed menouvers.

I don't hate it but i don't like it either. The targeting system is garbage have the time you will be fighting with it to target what you want it to. It works when it wants to basically and when it does work well you might so well in a fight. I don't bother with it half the time.

The one cool thing about this game is you can controll eidolons  unlike final fantasy 13 you can move then around. they each have there own moves and of course there signature moves like shiva for diamond dust ifrit hellfire  ect

I do like the stradgy battles they have throwen in i will let you discover thoughs on your own though it was a nice change of pace.


====================================================================================

Story .... ....  .....  .... ... ... ... ...  plot ?  ..... .... ... .... ... .....   crystals are controlling you   ... .... ....  mother is strange ....  ... ...  war blah blah blah ... yea you heard it all before i dont need to go into detail. Oh and machina is useless .....

====================================================================================

Music.
For the first time ... ever i have mixed feelings on a final fantasy soundtrack normally i like it all but half of it seemed bland and reused

For the tracks that were not reused  they were good  set the tone of the area nicely and the plot of the story was capture well through  some of the music.

====================================================================================
Voice acting

OMG  where do i start with this half of the characters did not sound like they should ..... Eights voice strange as hell aria's voice ? fricken annoying (in game joke)  dont get me started on the moogle  :/   just know the half the cast will annoy the heck out of you.

===================================================================================

Final verdict  ?

It pains me to not like a final fantasy game i just cant  get over some of the things that  could have used more work. Yes i know this is a psp port but thats no excusse for more polishing. It is ok to play though so even thoughi t could use improving here and there i would put is on the wishlist and wait for a sale.

I will however give this a reccomendation  because i just can't click on no.Just know that i am mixed on this one

reviewText:
Final Fantasy Type-0 is pretty cool, I guess.

Originally a PSP game exclusive to a mysterious island nation no one is actually sure exists, Type-0 is a spin off game part of a long lived video game franchise mainstream journalists pretend isn't as good as it actually is. Type-0 is part of the Fabula Nova Crystallis series of Final Fantasy games which includes Final Fantasy XIII and other games nobody actually cares for.

Luckily, outside of a few shared concepts, Type-0 lacks anything to do with the XIII trilogy so don't expect Toriyama's waifu to show up anytime soon.

You play as everybody. I mean Class-0, an organization of highly gifted individuals who work as special operatives for both the school they attend and their nations government. As a departure from other Final Fantasy games, Type-0 is told as a gritty war drama rather than a grand adventure across a continent.

The Militesi Empire, one of the four crystal states and named after their obvious love for humanitarian affairs, invades their neighboring Dominion of Rubrum while also dispatching a special unit directly to Akademia, the magic academy and capitol Rubrum. With the use of a special type of magitek armor that allowed them to jam the Vermilion bird Crystal and, in turn, block the use of magic to the academy cadets and legionaries on the ground. Without their big crutch or the use of Eidolins, this games summons, the Legionaries and Cadets are quickly overwhelmed and pushed to the verge of defeat.

That is until Class-0 arrives, who seem to be unaffected by the magitek's crystal jammer. With the use of magic, the Class-0 cadets push through the Militesi lines and make several surgical strikes on enemy positions which not only disrupted Militesi air superiority, but also destroyed the crystal jammer and allowed the Rubrum defenders to push back the enemy attack.

That's some WW2 ♥♥♥♥ right there.

The setting is probably Type-0's strongest aspect, while the Final Fantasy series is no stranger to war, it was never actually represented as the focal point of a game outside of maybe Final Fantasy Tictacs. I do love me some final fantasy Tictacs.

Every theme from the series itself is reiterated to do with military or war. Ultima becomes a weapon of mass destruction rather than just a spell, summons are used as wrecking balls on battlefields, there are plans that do fire magic bombing runs, and even with all that they managed to fit in things like human super weapons and giant robots.

Combat strays away from the usual FF formula, while random encounters are still a thing, every battle plays out in real time, and managing your parties health and mana works in conjunction with active dodging and finding openings for attacks. Timing your attacks at just the right time also counts towards a counter attack which lets you punch one clean chunk out of your enemies stomach. I mean, I'm no doctor or anything, but that doesn't seem possible, what with the bones, and cartilage, and organs.

Oh yeah, the characters.

Class-0 consists of fourteen characters, and while Ace seems to be the series representative of the party, each member seems to be as important as the other. Every character has their own skills and specialties, some are better at magic while others are better at getting in close, and others still work at dwindling down enemy HP from afar. Every character has a unique play style, and while some are obviously superior to others, it's still a neat way to add variety to your game. Or you could always just stand back with Trey and fire a charged bow at your enemies like a total coward.

By the way, they're all named after trumps. The cards, not the president candidate guy with the goofy hair.

I do have some gripes with the game, though. It was originally a PSP exclusive and it clearly shows, even with the updated HD graphics. And although 30 fps isn't a killer for me, I should probably point out that the game does not run at 60 fps and will sometimes dip with certain graphical settings on lower end hardware, it was no ways an actual deal breaker for me.

There's also a bit of a grind at certain points of the game, which makes sense considering what the original game was. And sometimes quest drops take so long to find you may as well just order them from Amazon.Rubrum and wait for them arrive a few weeks later. Some characters are also definitely more fleshed out and balanced than others on the battlefield, but the ones that aren't as good are still viable to use.

But should you play, Last Story: I can't actually make this joke because Last Story is an actual game now?

Yeh, I would say so, the game is constantly on sale if the full price isn't to your liking. There are also multiple endings for people who want to go back and give the game a few more runs, but in my opinion, the first ending is perfect for how the game is presented. Still, I have 30 some hours into the game and I'm probably going to go back to Orience sometime in the future.

Final Fantasy: Gritty War Story with teenagers gets 7 tragic battle scenes out of 10.

Now how long until we get a gritty Chocobo dungeon war story?


The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

reviewText:
Relevant specs:
FX-8320
R9 290
8GB DDR3 1600
Windows 10
360 controller

Port review: I haven't tried KB+M, because the design makes more sense to play with a controller in my opinion. Otherwise I've had no problems with the game. Steady frame rate with no noticeable drops using highest AA (rendering at 4k), no issues with video or sound playback. I'm very happy they gave us the option to set AA levels, and especially to turn off motion blur and  DoF. being a port from a handheld I'm surprised at how good the game looks. Overall it's definitely a very nice port, I believe this is the most effort I've seen in porting a console JRPG to PC. I hesitated a few days before purchasing due to all the negative reviews... but Steam reviews of ports are beginning to be completely worthless. A port can take a lot of time and care and give a lot of good options, but some insist on complaining no matter how much they get because there's always something that could be better. That's life. They didn't redesign the game from the ground up for the PC, they ported it. They did a good job of it, and I'm glad to have it.

reviewText:
Pros:
Fun Gameplay - There are many different characters to choose from and each plays completely differently. Switching characters often feels like starting a whole new game, keeping the action feeling fresh.
Beautiful Graphics
Gamepad controls are very tight
Nice level ramp - The game difficulty and character levels go up together at a nice rate and not too much grinding is needed to progress.

Cons:
Launcher is annoying - The graphics and control settings pop up each and every time you start the game, which isnt too bad except that controller support is confusing. This game pretty much has to be played with a controller but to select start game with a controller is not as simple as moving the joystick. You have to use the RB or LB buttons to move the curser down. Not too big a deal once I figured it out.
No exit game button - There is no button in game to exit game to desktop. You can either hit escape or if you start in big picture mode press the logo and then select exit game. Thats what I do and the reason why I get annoyed with the launcher and having to use the mouse to selct start game (until I found out I can use the RB button)
30 FPS lock

Overall this is a very enjoyable game. The story is interesting and the action battles are very fun. Its not a perfect game, but it is more than playable at this point and well worth your time.

reviewText:
When purchasing the game, I went into it with the mindset that this in fact a port of the PSP version of the game, a title that had only had a presense in Japan (barring English Patch work) and the news of seeing the recent 'HD' port going to PC would allow me the chance and opportunity to enjoy the title properly.
In my case, I had an enjoyable experience so far with the game, though this may vary from person-to-person on preference and approach to this title.

Voice work on English is barely passable, with either cringey dialogue, or very sub-par VA work; the better comparison of the team throwing the script to Google Translate, though character personalities are an even worse contentder (With exception to your two non-numbered party members Machina and Rem, though this is also a stretch pending your expected view to the game)

Gameplay will be your main bread-and-butter for this title, with a focus on using the various characters available (14 initially) to go with a particular style. Styles however may appear fairly limited, though do expand for a wider range as you level up. An example of this with the character of Queen (Longsword/Fencer) can allow for teleporting setup potential, something akin to the character Nightcrawler in speed, though still bland overall.

While I can recommend the game for play, I highly recommend waiting for further development if going for keyboard/mouse setup, with myself using a DS4 controller through the program InputMapper (Make it think it's a x360 controller)

reviewText:
Cons:
- 30fps (if that bothers you)
- voice acting and cut-scenes seem off
- few to no skill based achievements, a good portion unlock just for playing

Pros:
- Multiple playable characters makes combat fun
- New Game + feature
- Improvements over handheld versions graphics
- handy acceleration feature to speed up travel and combat

This game is darker than some other Final Fantasy games but it works well here. The number of playable characters gives you many options when taking on a new mission or when having trouble S ranking old missions. Missions can be replayed as well if you want to test new formations or just grind. This is not a remake but instead a remaster of a handheld; this becomes very noticable during cutscenes where you expect the usual over the top graphic treatment Square is known for but instead get the same handheld styled cutscenes. A good portion of cutscenes simply seem for lack of a better word slow and it takes you out of the experience to some extent. There are some decent cutscenes as well so it evens out somewhat. Side quests are present and give you some content to fool around with and the different difficulties and new game plus feature will definitely give hardcore fans something to do even after completing the game once. A pretty good game even with its faults.

reviewText:
+/+ Lots of characters, each with their own weapons and abilities, help to create a varied and fun combat system.  Combat is real-time and somewhat reminiscent of Parasite Eve or Kingdom Hearts.
+/+ Game includes option for Japanese voice acting and English subtitles.
+/+ Large amount of game content.  Lots of side quests, areas to explore, and people to talk to.  Type 0 is a 40+ hour base game with countless hours of additional content.
+/+ Excellent soundtrack and solid sound effects.
+/+ Overworld map, towns, and a game hub come together to create a world that feels alive and dynamic.
+/+ PC version supports an exclusive speed boost and a screenshot mode.
+/+ Three difficulties and new game +.

+/- Graphics are PS2 quality, which I find charming and nostalgic.  Others might find the graphics bland and undetailed.  Check out some videos or screenshots for an idea.
+/- Game requires some grinding on anything above the lowest difficulty.  If this is a problem, plan to play on easy.  That said, Type-0 is not an especially hard JRPG.

-/- Game is locked at 30 FPS, limited resolution options (720/1080 only), and many non-HD (or original PSP) textures.
-/- Many enemies, locations, towns, art assets, and environments are repeated throughout the game, which cases the mid-late game to feel more stale.
-/- Keyboard and mouse controls are terrible.  Plan to play with a controller or not at all.

Verdict: 7.5/10.  Type 0 is a solid action RPG.  The characters, setting, story, gameplay, and soundtrack are very good and mesh together well.  That doesn’t mean the game is without its problems, such as lack of keyboard/mouse controls and graphic options.  If you enjoy action JRPG’s and/or Final Fantasy, than it’s a no-brainer.  Otherwise, you should probably watch a video or two…

reviewText:
+ Looks gorgeous considering this is just an up-rezzed HD version of an orginal PSP title, and not a remake.
+ Camera is greatly improved from the PS4 and XBOX ONE versions.
+ The story is intricately crafted and has a very Final Fantasy VIII Vibe.
+ The Soundtrack is epic, featuring operatic vocals and rock melodies.
+ The battle system is fast and exhilarating. Think Final Fantasy XII meets Lightning Returns.
+ Solid exploration and replayablity, featuring optional paths and an alternate ending on multiple playthroughs.


- The game doesn't feature a native Half-Refresh Vsync option despite running at 30fps, but this can be forced through RadeonPro for both AMD and Nvidia.
- Resolution Support is limited but can be rendered in 4K by selecting highest Anti-Aliasing settings.
- A few framerate drops on highest settings even on a GTX 970 and i7-4790K, can be solved by lowering settings though.

reviewText:
This game is a poor excuse for even a port.

1. Consistantly crashes on a high end machine.
2. Jumps from 15-30FPS and is locked at 30FPS.  (I use a GTX 980)
3. Bad joystick support and no keyboard and mouse support, yet doesn't say a 360 controller is required on the store page.
4. 'HD' graphics are about as HD as Donkey Kong Jr on the Colecovision.  You can play it on 1080, but the graphics look no different.

If you already bought this, I'd recommend getting a refund.  If you pre-purchased it for the Dota2 items, get a refund and just wait until Sept. 2nd.  You will be able to buy those items on the Steam Marketplace dirt cheap at that point.

As long as the masses continue to buy bad ports, companies like this will continue to put out bad ports.  Vote with your money - Get a refund or don't buy at all.

This is coming from a fanboy who's been playing FF games since FF1 came out for the NES.

reviewText:
Great throwback to old final fantasies with a interesting battle system. What people seem to forget about the game is that it was originally an 2011 PSP game so keep that in mind when playing the game and enjoy it for what it is, an awesome handheld game with updated graphics, but hindered by the limitations of the original system.

PROS:
Versatile battle system with 14 characters that all play differently.
Great replay value with more content available each playthrough.
Lots of good content outside of the usual boring fetch quests you get in the beginning, like secret bosses, high level dungeons etc...
The main story plays like retelling of a historic war, pretty unique!
Lot's of cool references and Final Fantasy elements for long time fans.
Globe spanning war campaign where you feel like you are liberating areas from the other empire and taking key tactical positions.

CONS:
The camera, while improved, can still get pretty wild. You can change it in the settings though.
The story goes off the deep end at the end of the game and it's hard to understand if you don't play the game multiple times.
The cutscenes you can trigger with NPC's at school are pretty heavy on the anime tropes and they have a pretty big tonal shift from the grim main story.

All in all, a relly good game. Recommended!

reviewText:
A great game with some glaring flaws. First, you need to get over the overload of proper nouns that are completely new and don't make sense to you. Then you need to ignore that the camera is a fidgety little thing that gets hung up on the geometry and won't let you look at anything you need to look at. Then you need to get past that the characters are more or less tropey caricatures that aren't by any means deep or too real.

But underneath all that is a good plot that takes the realities of war on frankly, themes of death and the importance of rememberance, epic music, an actiony and competent battle system with 14 (fourteen!!) playable characters and plenty of side stuff to explore and flesh out the world. This is the first Final Fantasy game in years that I've been excited to play again and again to see more of the story and characters...as well as one of the only ones to leave me with an ending that made me FEEL things. (even if much of it doesn't make sense yet without the NG+ plot).

You're going to be confused, but if you're able to feel out a plot more than needing to understand every bit of it, this could be a game for you.

reviewText:
Better than you'd think for a PSP port.

Gameplay is Dynasty Warriors-esque with 14 (that I've seen) characters that are all fairly unique (balance is another issue).  Leveling up can be somewhat of a hassle when you're trying to keep everyone even (which is also annoying because only active participants gain XP while on missions).

Controls are good all things considered.  The game was designed with the PSP in mind and you can tell that they didn't half-♥♥♥ the port over to bigger and better systems.  Just something as simple as Confirm not being bound to a particular attack action.  It's amazing and I appreciate it.

Visuals are mediocre overall.  The Main characters look fine but secondary actors and some textures were obviously not given an HD makeover.  It can be a bit distracting if not hilarious.

The UI is solid other than in a few places (I'd have liked to be able to swap between characters on the equip/ability screens).  Squaresoft usually does well in this department so good on them.

Story and Themes are similar to FF Tactics.  The War is presented as dark and gritty.  The Setting is interesting and does some cool things with the four crystal mythology.  I hope for more final fantasies being written in the same vein (it won't though).

reviewText:
The gameplay is really awkward and clunky but if you get the hang of it, its still fun with a keyboard and mouse if your a keyboard war. I would suggest a controller over a keyboard for casual gamers. This game would probably work perfectly with a steam controller imo.

You get to control 3 simultaneous characters in combat somewhat. You actually can controll 1 at a time but can switch to the other characters with a push of a button. Keep in mind the characters that are not being controlled are running on autopilot. If 1 dies you get to choose from an array of other characters and call them into battle. There are 14 character in the game with different styles of fighting(from what i've seen...) there might be more.

The storyline is pretty solid and basically about territory wars and magic.

Nobuo Uematsu and some other guy are making the music. Need I say more.

The voice acting in this game is really good at some parts and others well...you'll see for you selves. They're lips, mouth movements and facial expressions never match what they're saying in both japanese and english so i don't get it :/ reminds me of dubbed jackie chan films lol.

If your a fan of ff games buy this game its still worth the 30 bucks, even better if its on sale. If your not a ff fan or an actoin rpg hack slash genre. I suggest stay away from this type of game. I'd give it a 7/10

reviewText:
First off - the game ran pretty smoothly at the normal settings with my PC setup.  If I turned up the settings on it, the game started getting framey, so it doesn't appear to be very well optimized.  However, the game looked fine on the normal settings and was pretty smooth throughout.

PROs
+ Very fun combat.  It is an action RPG, with some timing involved where you can do large amounts of damage to enemies if hit at the right time.  This system was well implemented and was fun to play.
+ Engaging story.  I liked the storyline in this game.  There were plenty of epic set pieces in the cutscenes and there was weight to what you were doing.
+ Bad-a characters.  All playable characters kick some serious butt and are all fun to play (even the flute had its moments)
+ Music was real good, especially a call back to one particular song :)

CONs
- Mission flow.  Each mission had these period of time in between where you roam around and do stuff, which got pretty annoying when I was just trying to finish the story.
- Too many seemingly unwinnable battles.  Now this could be just me, but there were a lot of battles in this game where it felt like I was getting cheaply killed.  And most of the time, losing this battle had no impact on the mission, as I completed the mission after dieing anyways.  And this happened numerous times... I am not a big fan of the unwinnable fight mechanic.
- The game was basically shoving new game + down my throat the entire time.  All of the trials, and a bunch of the tasks, were all way out of my level range.  So there were a lot of times when I would just skip to the mission day with several days left on the time remaining because I couldn't really do anything more.

Overall this was a fun game to play through, although I don't see myself playing through it a second time even though the game gated like half the content to that.  I would say it is worth the playthrough though.

reviewText:
Had a Blast!

This game did not dissapoint, I liked the story, graphics, gameplay and combat mechanics. The music was very nice as well.

Story: This world is either the same was FFX13 (the one with the MC Lightning) or similar, because there are L'Cie with their focus like in that one. I thought that was cool. Also, the world has a heck of a problem (a curse, IMO), I would absolutely HATE to live in that world. I won't spoil it for anyone. The setting has been done before, a class of super students saving the world, but what I like was the cast. There's some pretty cool characters in that class.

Graphics: I personally like it. More than good enough, and the cutscenes were pretty. There's room to nitpick here but honestly nothing stood out as BAD to me.

Gameplay (aside from combat mechanics): This is where some people will have bones to pick with the game. The monster spawns while travelling on the map are random. You can only save in certain places (somewhat annoying to me). You can only change your gear at the savepoints, what the heck?! Traveling at home base is a mild pain in the rear. Other than that, it was ok. Oh and I couldnt play it on my desktop because of some wierd regional setting?

Combat Mechanics: This is kind of a mixed bag but overall I loved it. You can do summons but I haven't had to and I never felt like I needed them, They should have made parts of the game where you absolutely had to summon an Eidolon. Missed opportunity there. Now about magic: another missed opportunity, because magic is clunky and a bit wierd to use at times, I felt it was much easier to use the character's special skills. Now THOSE shine! wow each character is different and has their own style, I ended up loving almost all of the characters styles! I absolutely loved training up the team and then wrecking the enemies with character skills alone. The one SUPER AWESOME part about the combat mechanics is that you can move, run, dodge, and time your crit hits, and the enemy can do the same! Its SOOOOO much better than not being able to move your characters like in the other Final Fantasy games. Seeing enemies throw themselves to the ground just to dodge your attacks is just way more realistic and fun! I totally LOVED the combat in this game.

Overall, Ioved the game, and totally reccomend it to Final Fantasy fans and RPG fans!

reviewText:

reviewText:
Final Fantasy Type-0 is a game I wish I could have enjoyed on my PS4.

Let me begin by addressing some of my original issues with the game.

The camera, this thing was dreaded, spun incredibly fast and made combat a huge drag that gave you motion sickness so long as you were prone to it(which I certainly am). The combat, this stemmed from the camera as I just said, having a poorly designed camera made dealing with more than one enemy at a time a misery. That was really it though, between motion sickness and dealing with enemies for way longer than necessary it ruined my experience.

Moving on though, has this game improved? Many of you seem to think it's horrific, that the game is near unplayable, that you need your mother and you need her now because only an adult can save you from this monstrosity that is Final Fantasy Type-0. It's so bad that I've gotten a girl pregnant even though I have a vasectomy. Just kidding, the improvements from those two issues are drastic.

I've only messed around a solid 15 min or so just to quickly see if the issues I had from my PS4 copy were still present, they weren't. The camera wasn't moving insanely fast when trying to look around or target enemies and following that handling with a few different enemies at once wasn't a chore and in fact simple to manage which is how a good targetting system should be.

Note: The camera isn't terrible in the PC release like people have claimed, while it's not the best I've ever played with, if you've even spent 5 minutes on PS4 or XB1 with it, this one begins to feel like the smoothest camera you've ever spun in your life.(The console was THAT bad. I'll say it's better than Devil May Cry camera angles to say the least rofl, which isn't saying much I'm sure most of you can agree xD.)

Moving on to everybody yapping about the FPS lock, it's 30 FPS, is 30 FPS doing any game justice in modern times? No. Is it making the game unplayable? Also no. It has a stable 30 FPS, something real JRPG players are very familiar with coming from xbox 360 and ps3 JRPGs. If you look past 60 FPS you'll notice something, you'll notice that the game is running flawlessly with no frame drops below 30 and that it looks smooth because of that. My friends, it's no different on the PS4 or XB1 versions.

Graphics... oh for the love of whatever god any of us believe in if you even do. Calm down, the game is a rescaled PSP game from 4 years ago. There will be some wonky textures and scaling issues present. It looks like a dated PS3 game and there's nothing wrong with that, don't set your standards of Type-0 to the height of the Empire State Building because Final Fantasy XIII looks like a modern next-gen game on PC. They're on two different engines this one on an engine designed to be compatible with mobile phone hardware, the other a poorly optimized engine that looks pretty but can't deliver. (Hence why 14 and 15 both aren't using Crystal Tools and using Luminous instead) The game is presentable and serves its purpose visually, that's fact not opinion.

Characters, every character is unique, 14 in total. Makes for the most diverse playable cast in any Final Fantasy thus far.

Lore, being part of the FNC series, Type-0 shares the same mythology as both 13 and 15. While neither of the games and their characters are related, there are a few references in Type-0 and rumored references in 15 to things we've heard of in 13. Majority of it not being anywhere even close to the same, but you get the idea.

Final Verdict?

Square did right by making me not need to take Dramamine in order to play their game, could they have made anything better? Probably, but let's be realistic here, it's not some kind of new game, this isn't the new FFVII where they're taking it and remaking it on Luminous Studio.

Final Fantasy Type-0 is an HD remaster of it's PSP predecessor that's also a fact, not an opinion.

So I recommend it to anybody like myself who wasn't able to experience it on PSP 4 or so years back.

I give it an 8/10 for the PC version. (Would have been a 6/10 had camera issues not have been fixed.)

reviewText:
Oh boy, where do I begin with this game?

First of all, do note that this game is a  PSP PORT  and is  LOCKED  at 30 fps. Now if you can get over these facts and is a crazy/loyal fan towards the Final Fantasy series, then by all means, get this game! I highly recommend it to the aforementioned category of people!

Graphics Let's start with the graphics because  everyone  is always so obssessed with it. Now, I'm gonna emphasize the fact that this game is a PSP port so do expect some things in the game -sometimes even cutscenes- to appear in low textures/quality because they ripped it straight out of the PSP version. Next is the FPS lock, now growing up, I've never gotten the chance to buy myself a powerful rig so my computers(including this one) is usually barely entry level to games or is exactly at the entry level so playing at constant 25fps-30fps is nothing new to me and if you're the same who has  adapted  to 30fps and below then this should NOT bother you. Unless of course, if the game is running at lesser than 20fps, then I think you have to change your settings abit. All in all though, graphics wise, if you're not one of those 'PC Masterrace' who always, always cry about graphics and have a decent rig, you will run this game smoothly.

Quick Heads up:  Setting your anti-aliasing to High and Very High will set the game to run textures at 2k and 4k respectively, so please keep that in mind before you try to pump things up

Gameplay Now, being a player of the original PSP version of Final Fantasy Type-0, I can tell you that there are  HUGE  amounts of tweaks here and there which I will not mention because there are simply too many. FF Type-0 is one of the more fast paced Final Fantasy game. You do not wait for turns nor do you wait for an action gauge to fill up. You have complete control of your character to run around and fight with, which makes the game easy to play and get into but hard to master. Though one thing I can't stand is the fact that you can only have 2 abilities equipped for you to use in battle and 1 defensive ability. This of course, excludes the normal attack ability. So in total, you will only have 4 abilties at your disposal.

Story To simplify things without spoiling anything, the game's protagonists are basically 14 chosen students who have the ability to save" Orience. Pretty bad summary

reviewText:
Final Fantasy type-0 is very diffrent from your avrage Final Fantasy game. The games comabt is real-time instead of turn-based and is very enjoyable. A lot of the people you can play as have very diffrent play styles makeing the game a lot more enjoyable if you get tired of noe play style. The game has an overall miltary conquest vibe going for it that I think was very well done and is what hooked me into the game. The next best thing about this game has to be the music. The music in type-0 is zome of my favorite from any Final Fantasy game and lots of time left me just standing in one area to take in the sounds. The stroy on the other hand was very underwelming. It wasen't that exciting and a lot of times I was itching to skip cut scenes since they got boring super fast. To add to that the final chapter was proabley one of the worst in video game history, but since I don't want to spoil anything you wil need to figer out why I feel that way on your own.


Overall I feel that this game is worth it for the very enjoyable combat and the music.
